text: ask any dog owner whether their pet can
sense their mood for the look on their
face and you're likely to get the same
answer
and absolutely hidden he just stares
with his big brown eyes and he really
reads my expression 100% no doubt about
it is there pup pup yeah and she's great
with my kids as well you know I can find
them so here up see she can get quite
distressed or she'll whine or she will
try and come and find me to let me know
and she definitely knows when I'm grumpy
I think he's pretty good at recognizing
facial movements expressions as well a
lot of empathy
maybe that's all in my head but that's
what I like to think at least in a
touchscreen experiment at this lab in
Austria scientists put canines to the
test
they showed dogs pictures of the eye or
mouth area of human faces that had
either happy or angry expressions half
the dogs got a treat too for nosing an
angry face the other half were rewarded
for touching happy faces
then came the test when the dogs were
shown happy or angry faced pictures of
people they hadn't seen before they were
still able to tell the difference and
earn their treat the scientists say
their experiment proves that dogs can
discriminate between the two expressions
and they think the animals use their
experience of how humans express
themselves to make that distinction it
is the first really strong evidence
empirical evidence that non-human
animals can differentiate between facial
expressions or emotional expressions of
an other species it's still not clear
though that our pets understand what our
emotional expressions mean but there was
one other intriguing clue from this
study before they were taught the rules
of the touchscreen test
dogs had a natural aversion to pressing
their noses against pictures of angry
faces so that could mean that our canine
friends have an inkling about the
meaning behind a very human look
something that many dog lovers
will agree with Victoria Gill BBC news
